column2: It's not Voodoo - Creating your own mouse cursor!
What you'll do
Create your very own mouse pointer (cursor) that you can use across the entire operating system!

Uh-oh! It looks like GIMP isn't installed! You need to download it from the App Center if you want to play this activity. Click the icon named App Center on the Desktop, search for GIMP and install it, then restart this activity.
Greetings, {{user_name}}. I thought I'd show you a fun way to customize the operating system, today.
Have you played with the System App at all yet? If not, you could to try the "Touring the System" activity before this one, if you want.

At any rate, in the System App, you could switch your mouse cursor between various different objects - Cheese, a Unicorn, et cetera. You probably had your own idea of what would be a fun cursor, though.
Good news - today, we're going to make a brand-new cursor, just for you!
I'll open up GIMP to start us off - It's an image editing program, a little like Photoshop, if you've heard of that. You can find it on the Desktop if you'd like to use in on your own, later.

Good, now let's open a template file I've prepared for you. Press (Ctrl + O) to open a file and the dialog will start you out in your Recently Used files. Use the left-hand part of the window to navigate to your Documents folder, inside your home directory - remember that from your previous experiences with creating files and directories?
Inside the Documents folder, you should see a file named cursor_template.xmc. Double-click it to open it.

This image is a little... small, isn't it? To be precise, it's 32 pixels tall, and 32 pixels wide. Nice and tidy. Let's zoom in, so you can get a better look. Press Z to activate the zoom tool, and click on the center of the image a few times to zoom in. If you go too far, hold Ctrl and click to zoom out.

Now, that's better. You can edit this image as you like - or just add a little color. Press Shift + B or click on the Bucket Fill Tool on the left side of the screen, then click the black box in front of the white box below the tools to set the color. Color the inside of the gear however you like.

That looks fine. See the big, black triangle up and to the left of the gear? I put that there so there'd be an obvious click point for this cursor. Now, let's get this cursor into a file type that the operating system can understand as a cursor. Click File, then Export As.
You'll see a save dialog pop up - it should be asking to save it as cursor_template.xmc, but we need to name it something else. Instead, it should be called mycursor.xmc. Now, click Export.

Another window will pop up, and this is where we would set the "clicking target" of the cursor, as well as the timing of an animation the cursor might have, if you were making an hourglass or watch cursor for the "busy" state, maybe. Fortunately, I've already set these, so you can just click Export (yes, for the second time).
Now we've got a cursor file! There are still a few things we need to do so the operating system can recognize it, though. I'll open up the Terminal for you - we'll need it for the next few steps.
Hopefully you started off in your home directory (~). Just to make sure, type cd ~ and then press Enter to make sure we're there.

Now, let's delve into the inner workings of the OS. For the next set of instructions, be very careful to type them all in exactly as shown - the files and directories in this part only function if they have specific names.

Try typing cd .icons and then pressing Enter (Notice the period in front of the folder name). If that worked, excellent. If it produced an error, type mkdir .icons, press Enter, and then type cd .icons and press Enter.
Now that we're in the .icons directory. Type ls and press Enter to see what's here. If you created this directory, it'll be empty, if not, there might already be some cursors set up.
Let's make our own directory for our cursor - Type mkdir cursor-gear, press Enter, then cd cursor-gear (and press Enter) to go inside.
Now, let's get everything in place in this directory. We need to make a small file that tells the operating system that we're only replacing the default cursor. Type nano index.theme and press Enter.
In this file, type the following: [Icon Theme] and then, on the next line, type Inherits=Adwaita
Now you can press Ctrl + O (O like in Orange) to start the save, press Enter to confirm the filename, and then Ctrl + X to exit back to the Terminal.
Almost there! Let's make another new directory and go into it - mkdir cursors then cd cursors

Now we need to get that cursor file we made with GIMP into this directory. To copy, we use cp, and add the place where the file is (our Documents folder), then the place we need the file to go (this folder, which you can see in your prompt). Think of what that might look like...
The command we need is cp ~/Documents/mycursor.xmc ./ Note the space after .xmc ! ./ is shorthand for "the directory we're in". Now, press Enter to confirm the command.
Let's double-check to make sure that worked - type ls and press Enter again, and confirm that you see a file named mycursor.xmc in this directory.

One last file operation - We need to rename this file in order for the operating system to recognize it. Type mv mycursor.xmc left_ptr then press Enter. Remember that moving a file to one with a different name is essentially renaming it.
OK! Let's type in ls one last time to make sure the rename worked. If you see a file named left_ptr, it's time to tell the OS to change your cursor!
Type gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.interface cursor-theme cursor-gear and then press Enter... and you should see your image replace the mouse cursor!
Excellent work! Now, if you wanted to restore the previous cursor, you could type gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.interface cursor-theme cursor-hack and then press Enter.
You've done a fantastic job, {{user_name}}! Now everyone's going to know that this machine is yours, and if they argue... the proof is in the pointer! I'll see you next time, keep on Hacking!
